div.head: A MILITARY SCANDAL
div.p: The Report of the Royal Commission on War Stores in South Africa is not only in itself a very painful document but it cannot fail to arouse serious misgivings as to matters which did not fall within the purview of the Commissioners. It is bad enough to be told that the total preventable loss to the home taxpayer during the 22 months after the Peace lies somewhere between three-quarters of a million sterling and one and a quarter million sterling. But the real sting of the Report to our mind (says the "Globe") consists of the general impeachment of the foresight and business capacity of the implicated officials, civil and military. The Commissioners have placed on record incidentally their conviction that no private firm could avoid bankruptcy if it allowed its agents to deal with business matters in the mode in which certain officers of high rank in the Army Service Corps have dealt with the purchase and sale of supplies. The same reflection is forced upon the reader of the Report, only with a much wider and. more universal application. If an Empire like ours cannot get better yalue out of its servants, and cannot exact a higher standard of ability and integrity, the day of decline and fall cannot be very far distant. On the general question of corruption, indeed, the Commissioners do not find that the, sweeping innuendos of Sir William Butler and his col- leagues have any solid foundation in fact.Certain officers and non-commissioned, officers have gravely misconducted themselves, and their fate is left to the military authority A censure, severe, but, in our judgment hardly severe enough, is passed upon Colonel Morgan: it is all the more to be deplored when the Commissioners admit that officer to be a man of exceptional capacity in the Army Service Corps whose career had been one of rapid and deserved success. It is very unpleasant, als, to find that the Army Service. Corps regulations forbidding social inter course with contractors were habitually disregarded by officials holding positions of great responsibility. The Army Service Corps emerges from the inquiry with a heavy stain on what had been a brilliant record, and its personnel will require a drastic purging

But, as we have said before, the main interest of the inquiry lies in its revelations of the incapacity of the Military authorities and of the War Office to deal with a situation which must have been foreseen months before it actually took shape. All through the spring of 1902 it was patent to those in authority that the Boer resistance was weakening, that the end might come at any moment, and that a prodigious amount of Army stores would have to be disposed of. Lord Kitchener, indeed, had made provision for winding up the financial side of the war by appointing Major Armstrong as Financial Adviser to the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief; and the ink was scarcely dry on the Vereeniging treaty when he created the sales department for taking over all surplus stores, and entrusted its organization to Colonel Morgan, who, up to that date, was fully deserving of the confidence of his superiors. Unhappily, Lord Kitchener left Africa almost immediately after the war was at an end, and from that date chaos ensued. The South African military command was divided into three, but through an omission, the responsibility of which is not travel, Major Armstrong was given no place in the reconstruction. And thus a post which Lord Kitchener considered of vital importance during the critical period of demobilization and the disposal of supplies and stores was left in abeyance. Worse than this, the detail- ed arrangement, administrative and financial, necessary for carrying the division of the command into practical working operation" seems to have altogether escaped the attention of the Quartermaster General's department for nearly three months, while the Finance Department of the War Office issued no in- structions at all. One step, however, was taken towards the end of August. Orders came out from England recalling Colonel Morgan, and appointing Colonel Hipwell as Director of Supplies in his place. This substitution was not due to any distrust of Colonel Morgan, but to a mere pedantic adhesion to the principles of seniority, regardless of experience and capacity. The Commissioners acquit Colonel Hipwell of direct misconduct, but they make their opinion of his unfitness for the post perfectly apparent.

Among the consequences of Colonel Morgan's recall was the enormous loss sustained by the working of the local contract system. It was originally devised by him with the approval of Lord Kitchener, and entailed the disposal on the spot of the surplus stores to local on- tractors, and their re-purchase from time to time without drawing fresh supplies from home. Under an exceptionally capable officer it might possibly have succeeded, though the odds are strongly against it; and when once the fatal entanglements with Meyer (Limited) had been entered into, its fate was sealed. Colonel Morgan was largely, but not solely, responsible for this arrangement, and his conduct in getting a highly-paid berth in that concern for his brother was most censurable. Had he remained at the head of affairs, his knowledge and ability might have checked some of the grosser abuses, but Colonel Hipwell was a child in the hands of the Philistines. He had not devised the system of local contracts, and had had no part in its recommendation, But he and his subordinate, Captain Limond, not only accepted it without examination or protest, but with a whole-hearted devotion worthy of a better cause they strove to give the system the appearance of a working concern, "they sacrificed public money, abandoned legal rights and equitable claims, and by continual subsidy and concession, succeeded in giving to the contractors a false semblance of activity." The miserable story of the contractors and their victims, of the criminal careless- ness of some officers, of the incredible reckless- ness of others, was told in the daily reports of evidence taken before the Commission. The real guilt lies with those who allow so vital a department of the Army to be improperly, and insufficiently staffed, and with the War Office clerks in the finance department ar home, who neglected the whole series of transactions in South Africa, and resented all efforts at inquiry. One of these, a worthy successor of Tite Barnacle in "Little Dorrit," suggested that if the Controller and Auditor-General persisted in his inquiries he should be "told to mind his own business." The Coar missioners have also to complain of the carelessness and indifference of the military authorities in South Africa, and it is apparent that the inquiries prosecuted under their directions in the sub-Continent met with ill-disguised obstruction. The Commissioners have discharged a most difficult and invidious task in at manner commensurate with their high reputation
